The College of Fine Arts (CFA) at Boston University consists three schools: The School of Music, the School of Theatre, and the School of Visual Arts. Each school offers degrees in the performing and visual arts at both the undergraduate and graduate level. In order to gain admission into the college, a live or pre-recorded audition is required for music and theatrical performance majors and a portfolio for visual arts and technical theatre majors.
The School of Music
The School of Music was founded in 1872 and is the oldest degree-granting music program in the U.S. The school offers a Bachelor of Music (BM) , a Master of Music (MM) and the Doctorate of Musical Arts (DMA). Some of the available concentrations include Music Theory and Composition, Musicology, Music Education and Conducting. The school has 150 faculty members which allows easy access to individual studio instructions.
The School of Visual Arts
The school of Visual Arts was founded in 1954. It offers a Bachelor of Fine Arts (BFA) and a Master of Fine Arts (MFA) in graphic design, art education, sculpture and painting. There are four on-campus galleries that exhibit students work throughout the year, the BU Art Gallery, the Commonwealth Gallery, the 808 Gallery and there Sherman Gallery. Facilities include a computer lab, a new media room, a welding ship, a wood shop, and painting, printmaking and photography studios.
The School of Theatre
The School of Theatre is a conservatory-style training program that focuses on collaboration and ensemble. The school offers a Bachelor of Fine Arts (BFA) and Master of Fine Arts (MFA) and Artisan Certificates for students studying technical theatre. For BFA degrees, possible areas of study include acting, theatre arts, stage management and theatrical design and production. There are four theaters, and in 2017, the CFA Production Center opened its state-of-the-art-theatre.
